In fact the Government was then in the process of altering the arrangements so that all benefit recipients would pay at least 20 percent of their local tax bill (UK Government, 1986 — Reform of Social Security).

This equation is derived as follows. The equation for calculating grant at low levels of grant was given by: Grant = Exp -( f Exp-GREAI ß + GRP*}.RV.Xier I L pop J > where Exp is expenditure, ß is a parameter determined by the Government (set to 0.69 in 1985/86) and GRP* is the standard rate poundage for spending at GREA. It should be noted that this formula secures the objectives of needs and resource base equalisation noted above. The formula for marginal grant rate is obtained by taking the derivative of this equation with respect to Exp.

In fact the situation was more complex than given here. For high levels of spending the factor 0.69 was increased by 25 per cent, resulting in a decrease in MGR. Moreover, there was a complex system of grant penalties superimposed on the block grant system (see Smith and Stewart (1985)). Under these circumstances, some authorities would face a lower level of MGR, but for reasons of simplicity we use only the standard MGR in this paper.

It might be imagined that a simpler measure than MBR, such as the percentage of rateable value in the business sector, might be adequate for capturing the effect of business rates. Indeed Paying for Local Government does implicitly suggest such a measure. However, the grant system did seek to equalise differences in the constitution of local rateable value, so the suggested measure MBR is more theoretically sound.
Throughout this paper all coefficients are multiplied by 100.
